title: The Apprentice candidates exposed in 'display of incompetence that gives sales a bad name'
text:

The Apprentice candidates failed miserably in Wednesday night's challenge in one of the worst displays of sales skills in the show's history.

Business and sales expert Richard Hilton believes their lack of sales knowledge was exposed in a 'display of incompetence that gives sales professionals a bad name'.

The EMEA Managing Director at Miller Heiman Group, a leading global consultancy that has defined modern selling, was shocked by the lack of planning and attention to detail.

Kenna Ngoma was given the chop by Lord Sugar - but Richard believes that another candidate deserved to be sent home.

There was only one candidate out of the hopefuls that he believes showed any sales skills, which doesn't look good for future weeks.

(Image: BBC)

Giving his expert opinion, Richard says: “From a selling perspective, all contestants categorically failed in last night’s episode with a display of incompetence that gives sales professionals a bad name. Each contestant presented themselves as being able to sell and think strategically but neither ability was evident from anyone when it came to the crunch.

“The collective ignorance of selling was summed up by Ryan-Mark’s assertion that being a great public speaker is all you need for a negotiation. This is utterly false. Being a professional salesperson means that you have a clear strategy, but the lack of this was a recurring theme throughout for both the boys’ and the girls’ teams.

(Image: BBC)

(Image: BBC)

The girls looked very unprofessional when they came out of their pitch to discuss figures, while the boys didn't arrange an actual time to meet their client.

Richard says: "We saw no pre-pitch planning, no definition of objectives and no identification of the margin that would allow them to understand their minimum price. Before walking into any negotiation, it is imperative to do your homework on the prospective client and be clear of the target price and how to deal with a discount based on number of items wanted.

"Equally important is knowing what role each team member will take – who explains the product, who understands the client’s needs and who captures all the information. Unforgivably, it transpired that not a single team member had taken any notes!"

(Image: BBC)

The boys' corporate client was stunned when they turned up with their unimpressive ice lollies and even pointed out their "rude" shape.

They tried to reduce their price dramatically from £3.85, even offering them up at a mere £1.25, but the client refused to buy any for more than a pound.

Richard believes that Lord Sugar was wrong to fire Kenna - and that Dean should have been sent packing from the competition.

(Image: BBC)

(Image: BBC)

Analysing the teams, Richard says: “What we witnessed from both teams was a complete disregard for any strategy and an eagerness to only concentrate on price – when negotiating, there are many elements at play, not just price.

“Had Dean fully understood the margin, he would have recognised that the offer of £1 per ice-lolly was still profitable. However, the lack of strategy and communication amongst the team meant that he was blind to this, the offer was declined, and the boys walked away patting themselves on the back. For this reason, I think that Dean should have been fired – he got it wrong and was too fixated on being seen as the star deal maker.

“At least the girls got somewhat of a deal, especially since the product was poor – but we still experienced poor negotiation. With no idea on price, mark-up, strategy around the deal and team roles – plus having to break from the meeting to come back with nothing new to offer – this was professionally inadequate, and no deal would have succeeded in the real world. They clearly didn’t invest time in covering the basics around the product, margin and deal dynamics."

The only candidate that impressed Richard with their selling skills was Tommy Skinner, who was praised by Claude Littner for his sales technique.

He adds: "The only display of selling skill came from Tommy – but as a life-long market trader, the poor product quality was offset by his charismatic selling style.

"His past experience allowed him to work out very quickly how long to spend on each potential buyer; understanding interest and persuasion to buy. The rest were a bit of a wet weekend."

*The Apprentice airs Wednesdays on BBC One at 9pm
description: EXCLUSIVE: Business and sales expert Richard Hilton was stunned by the candidates' 'unforgivable' mistakes - and thinks Lord Sugar got it wrong
